I.  THE PROPOSAL 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed 
policy-based  grant  to  the  Independent  State  of  Samoa  for  the  Public  Sector  Financial 
Management Program. 
 
2.  The program is designed to improve the Government of Samoa’s (government) capacity 
in public financial management and to strengthen the country’s resilience to external shocks by 
supporting the government’s medium-term fiscal framework (MTFF) and the joint policy action 
matrix  (JPAM)  on  public  financial  management  policies  and  processes,  developed  by  the 
government and its development partners.1 
  
II.  THE PROGRAM 
A.  Rationale 
3.  Samoa  is  a  small  and  remote  Pacific  island  country  with  a  population  of  close  to 
200,000. It has limited natural resources,  a narrow economic base, is isolated and poorly 
connected, and is highly vulnerable to external shocks – such as global economic changes and 
natural disasters. These factors have constrained economic growth and contributed to a high 
degree of volatility in economic performance. As a result, the economy has a high reliance on 
remittances and development assistance to underpin steadfast and sustained growth.  
 
4.  The government has demonstrated a strong commitment to doing what is necessary to 
generate sustainable economic growth. Since the 1990s, it has made considerable progress in 
developing  and  implementing  policy,  legal,  and  structural  reforms  designed  to  strengthen 
institutions;  improve  productivity;  create  an  enabling  environment  for  private  sector 
development; improve the performance of state-owned enterprises (SOEs); strengthen budget 
processes; and tighten expenditure controls.2 In 2008, this culminated in the launch of phase 1 
of the public financial management reform plan (PFMRP), which aims to strengthen public 
financial management systems to promote the efficient use of resources for the public good. 
Phase 1 was completed in early 2011; phase 2 is underway and expected to end in late 2014.  
 
5.  The  government’s  perseverance  in  implementing  the  reforms  necessary  for 
macroeconomic  stability,  its  outward  orientation,  prudent  fiscal  policy,  and  investment  in 
infrastructure helped the economy grow by nearly 4.0% per annum in the decade leading up to 
2008. During fiscal year (FY) 2008, the fiscal deficit was 1.5% of gross domestic product (GDP) 
while public debt was well within the limits of affordability at 35.2% of GDP. Moreover, the 
government had made steady progress in achieving poverty reduction and social development 
through a combination of reforms and effective use of development assistance. 
 
6.  However,  since  2009,  Samoa’s  economy  has  been  affected  by  a  series  of  severe 
external shocks. The global economic crisis and the related slowdown in demand triggered a

2  
sharp downturn of the economy as tourism, manufacturing, and agriculture receipts fell. This 
was closely followed by a devastating tsunami in September 2009, which caused substantial 
damage to infrastructure, homes, and livelihoods. The combination of these events led to a 
5.1% decline in GDP in FY2009. Reconstruction and key public investments laid the basis for 
the resumption of growth but at the expense of large deficits and escalating public debt. In 
response to this, the government embarked on a program of reforms aimed at consolidating 
fiscal adjustment to strengthen the economy’s resilience to possible future shocks, particularly 
natural disasters. Budget support from ADB, Australia, New Zealand, and the World Bank to 
assist  the  Strategy  for  the  Development  of  Samoa  (SDS),  2012–2016  enabled  actions  to 
mitigate impacts on the most vulnerable in society, advance public financial management and 
SOE reforms in a difficult fiscal environment, and put in place systems to better respond to the 
frequent natural disasters in Samoa.3  
 
7.  In December 2012, Samoa was hit by another natural disaster, tropical cyclone Evan, 
which caused damages and loss to the economy, estimated at more than $210 million (about 
30% of GDP), damaging transport, power, water, and sanitation infrastructure, as well as school 
buildings and housing. With the economy still underperforming after the earlier shocks, the 
government turned to development partners to help deepen and extend the efforts made under 
previous reforms, and to assist with the fiscal adjustment needed in the medium term to ensure 
debt sustainability. A key element of this has been the formulation of the MTFF, linked to the 
JPAM, which charts a clear path to bringing the government’s fiscal position to more sustainable 
levels  over  a  period  of  3–5  years,  while  maintaining  aggregate  demand  and  improving 
productivity. The plan aims at protecting the economy against future crises while laying the 
basis for sustained economic growth by (i) helping the government implement its structural 
reform program to improve medium-term growth prospects and (ii) adopting mitigation strategies 
to strengthen climate resilience. The latter include climate-proofing of economic infrastructure 
and incorporating disaster risk preparedness into the design of reconstruction investments. This 
two-pronged approach is consistent with the objectives of the SDS, which recognizes that a 
foundation of macroeconomic stability, fiscal stability, and stronger resilience to exogenous 
shocks is essential to restoring Samoa to a path of inclusive growth and poverty reduction.  
 
8.  The latest shock will delay the return to a more sustainable fiscal position. The GDP 
growth estimate for FY2013 is 0.9%. GDP is projected to increase to 3.1% in FY2014 and 2.6% 
in FY2015 as post-cyclone reconstruction starts; but is forecast to level off at 2.5% thereafter. 
The overall fiscal deficit is estimated at 6.9% of GDP in FY2013 and is projected to increase to 
8.2%  in  FY2014.  The  government,  however,  is  firmly  committed  to  achieving  fiscal 
sustainability; hence its MTFF sets out a program of fiscal adjustment with a deficit target of 
3.5% of GDP in FY2016 (Table 1). Samoa has limited capacity to take on more debt to support 
economic  recovery.  The  2013  World  Bank–International  Monetary  Fund  (IMF)  Debt 
Sustainability Analysis raised Samoa’s debt distress classification from moderate to high and 
estimated that any increase in concessional loans from development partners could see the 
debt to GDP ratio exceeding 70% of GDP by FY2015.4 Recognizing this, both ADB and the 
World Bank shifted from a mixture of 50:50 credit and grant financing to a 100% grant financing 
in June 2013. The MTFF presents a ratio of debt to GDP of 50% by FY2020.5 More broadly, in 
May 2013, the IMF approved balance of payments support of $9 million under its Rapid Credit

9.  In  the  short  term,  undertaking  a  cyclone  recovery  program  requires  a  period  of 
expansionary  fiscal  activity  and  will,  inevitably,  add  to  the  public  debt  burden.  Public 
investments will increase sharply, straining Samoa’s stressed financial management systems. 
As these investments increase, it is essential that public spending delivers value for money. In 
the medium term, Samoa will need to restore fiscal sustainability and continue with efforts to 
grow  its  private  sector.  Attempting  fiscal  consolidation  on  the  demand  side  involves 
incorporating  climate  resilience  measures  into  the  design  of  reconstruction  investments  to 
mitigate future losses and expenditure demands in the event of disasters.  
 
1.  Government’s Policy Reform Matrix for Budget Support 
10.  Drawing on progress made and priorities set under the PFMRP, the government, along 
with ADB, the Australian Agency for International Development (AusAID), the European Union 
(EU), the IMF, the New Zealand Aid Programme, and the World Bank, agreed to the JPAM in 
March 2013.7 The JPAM prioritizes policy reforms in five areas: (i) strengthening planning, (ii) 
enhancing  the  contribution  by  SOEs,  (iii)  improving  public  financial  management  systems, 
(iv) maintaining  overall  macroeconomic  stability  and  fiscal  discipline,  and  (v) deepening 
consultation and engagement with stakeholders. The emphasis of the JPAM on public financial 
management, good governance, and macroeconomic management is fully consistent with the 
SDS. While supporting the overall objective of the JPAM but unlike AusAID and NZ—which 
adopted the full JPAM—ADB and the World Bank, in consultation with the government, agreed

4  
to adopt a subset of the JPAM, and actions relating to climate resilience, for their respective 
programs. A copy of the JPAM is in the supplementary appendixes. 
 
11.  Development partners have assisted the government in implementing reform priorities 
through  technical  advisory  support.  ADB  has  supported  SOE  reforms  and  internal  audit 
processes, the World Bank has supported reforms in public debt management, and the Pacific 
Financial  Technical  Assistance  Centre  and  the  IMF  have  been  closely  involved  in  policy 
discussions on fiscal reforms. In addition to the program, ADB’s support for implementing the 
JPAM  continues  through  regional  technical  assistance  such  as  the  Strengthening  Public 
Financial  Management  in  Pacific  Developing  Member  Countries8 and  the  Private  Sector 
Development Initiative.9 All support from development partners will help the government build 
capacity for public financial management and accomplish the policy actions contained in the 
JPAM. 
 
12.  While the program is not a cofinancing arrangement, it is integral to a joint undertaking 
with  other  development  partners  to  help  meet  the  JPAM-related  financing  gap  through 
independent, policy-based budget support. In this regard, during FY2014, Australia will disburse 
about $6.0 million and New Zealand $0.7 million as the final tranche of a 3-year budget support 
program.10 The World Bank approved budget support for $15.0 million in June 2013. 
 
13.  The program is anchored in the government’s MTFF. It is structured around four outputs: 
(i) improved SOE performance by reforming corporate governance, (ii) improved public financial 
management systems, (iii) improved public debt management, and (iv) recovery and resilience 
to natural disasters. The outputs will be achieved through a set of policy actions drawn from the 
JPAM and from the cyclone recovery program.  
 
14.  The program is part of a sequenced, medium-term effort to assist the government in 
strengthening its public financial management. It builds on the results and lessons from ADB’s 
previous assistance, the Economic Recovery Support Program,11 and from ADB’s support for 
reform around the region. The recovery support program was completed in a timely manner. 
Some key lessons are: (i) the government must own the program; (ii) reforms must be politically 
as well as technically feasible; (iii) the program’s policy actions need to be focused and take into 
account  the  country’s  context;  (iv)  stakeholders,  including  development  partners,  must 
understand that reforms in the Pacific context can take time to become self-sustaining; and 
(v) “champions for change” contribute to the success of policy-based operations.12 Reforms in 
small Pacific islands like Samoa cannot take place overnight. Policy reforms and policy actions 
need to be realistic and factor in a slower pace, i.e., they cannot be too ambitious.

2.  State-Owned Enterprise Performance 
15.  Reforming SOEs is essential to improving public financial management. Samoa has 
27 SOEs with estimated total assets of $618 million. SOEs account for 6% of GDP, 12% of 
formal  sector  employment,  and  32%  of  public  sector  employment.  SOEs  provide  most 
infrastructure services and operate numerous businesses, which crowds out the private sector. 
Inefficient  SOEs  have  resulted  in  high  costs  of  doing  business,  thus  limiting  Samoa’s 
competitiveness. Returns on government investment in SOEs have been low—between FY2002 
and FY2010, the average return on equity of Samoa’s SOEs was 0.3% and their average return 
on assets was just 0.2%.13 Poorly performing SOEs are a drain on the government’s budget. 
  
16.  The Public Bodies (Performance and Accountability) Act in 2001 (Public Bodies Act) and 
the subsequent policy paper on SOE ownership, performance, and divestment established the 
principles by which the government places its SOEs on a commercial footing and divests non-
strategic SOEs. Progress has been made in fostering corporate governance  by moving to 
independent boards of directors and capacity development for potential directors, intended to 
help SOEs focus on their commercial mandate. Implementation of both the act and the policy 
has  been  slow,  primarily  due  to  limited  technical  capacity  and  the  government’s  cautious 
approach to SOE divestment. Although the government’s intention is to retain 100% ownership 
of the major infrastructure SOEs, policy allows private sector participation in these SOEs.  
 
3.  Public Financial Management Systems Development 
17.  The government is committed to public financial management reforms. Phase 1 of the 
PFMRP was completed in early 2011. Its achievements included the formulation of an aid policy 
and debt management strategy, a full review of all finance sector systems and procedures, and 
the adoption of an outcome-based budget with forward estimates. Twelve sector plans were 
completed, but most still needed to finalize the associated expenditure and monitoring and 
evaluation frameworks. The first phase of an institutional strengthening program for the Ministry 
of Revenue was also initiated. The government is now implementing phase 2 of the PFMRP, 
such as finalizing the internal audit strategy, preparing a debt management reform plan, and 
moving toward a fully operational MTFF. A budget performance framework was introduced in 
the FY2012 budget seeking to better link outcomes and outputs. A small procurement division is 
now functioning within the Ministry of Finance (MOF) and is leading procurement reforms.  
 
4.  Strengthening Public Debt Management 
18.  Outcome 1 of the SDS is macroeconomic stability. To achieve this, the SDS aims to 
continue strengthening public financial management, and implementing and monitoring the debt 
management strategy. It sets a target budget deficit of no more than 3.5% of GDP and a target 
debt–GDP ratio of less than 50%. It also aims to improve the scores from the 2010 Public 
Expenditure and Financial Accountability (PEFA) assessment, keep underlying inflation at 3%–
4% annually and the real exchange rate competitive, and improve the enabling environment for 
access to credit by the private sector. The real annual GDP growth target is 3%–4%.  
 
19.  Despite proactive debt management and a clear fiscal strategy, the small size of the 
economy relative to the recent economic and climatic shocks has meant that debt-related risk 
has progressively increased. Since 2009, debt has risen rapidly as a result of more government 
                                                
13 ADB. 2012. Finding Balance. Benchmarking the Performance of State-Owned Enterprises in Papua New Guinea. 
Manila.

6  
borrowing  to  finance  development  and  capital  projects,  as  well  as  to  counter  a  series  of 
exogenous shocks. The 2013 World Bank–IMF Debt Sustainability Analysis for Samoa finds 
that sustainability of public external debt is a major risk, as evidenced by the shift in country 
classification from moderate to high risk of debt distress. Careful monitoring and constant 
vigilance is therefore required to restore debt levels to more manageable territory.  
 
5.  Investing in Climate Resilience 
20.  Improving climate resilience has important implications for public financial management. 
Climate-proofing infrastructure and homes will increase investment costs, but should reduce the 
budgetary burden in future years if climatic shocks occur. Stronger climatic resilience will also 
bolster investor confidence, with positive effects on growth and revenues. Flooding caused 
much damage during cyclone Evan. The cyclone and flooding destroyed many houses and 
temporarily displaced 7,500 people. The post-disaster needs assessment recommended that 
new regulations and procedures be introduced to the development of a town plan, to limit the 
risk for new houses built in high-risk areas. The government’s home-rebuilding scheme requires 
that new homes are built to cyclone- and flood-resilience standards.  
 
B.  Impact and Outcome 
21.  The intended impact of the program is to achieve long-term fiscal stability. The impact 
will be assessed against the achievement of the government’s targets for fiscal deficit and 
external public debt. The outcome of the program will be improved fiscal management with a 
special  focus  on  climate  resilience.  The  program  will  be  anchored  in  a  macroeconomic 
framework that is agreed on with the IMF and aims to restore long-term fiscal sustainability. 
 
C.  Outputs 
22.  Output 1: Improved state-owned enterprise performance by reforming corporate 
governance. SOE reforms have been implemented to improve SOE performances. Under the 
JPAM, the government has steadily reduced the number of public servants and elected officials 
on SOE boards to comply with the Public Bodies Act. The government developed an SOE 
performance framework of key financial indicators and established a reporting mechanism for 
MOF monitoring and to avail reports publicly. One SOE will be privatized, with another in the 
pipeline. Lastly, the government will review its privatization policy, taking into account a public–
private partnership framework being developed with World Bank support.  
 
23.  The program will support three tranche 1 policy conditions: (i) 100% compliance with the 
Public Bodies Act on board appointments by the 16 SOEs classified as public trading bodies; (ii) 
approval of the SOE performance framework; and (iii) publication of consolidated report on the 
MOF website. Under the second tranche, the program will support: (i) the approval of the 
public–private  partnership  framework;  and  (ii)  the  review  of  the  government’s  privatization 
policy, including a time-bound plan for future SOE divestitures. Tranche 2 conditions will be 
completed by 31 December 2014. 
 
24.  Output  2:  Improved  public  financial  management  systems.  To  continue 
strengthening public financial management systems, under the JPAM (i) a PEFA assessment 
will be undertaken and published; (ii) a public expenditure review will be completed; (iii) a joint 
procurement  review  will  be  completed  and  a  procurement  reform  implementation  strategy 
approved; (iv) quarterly arrears reports will be prepared and circulated; and (v) an internal audit 
strategic plan will be implemented.

7 
25.  The  program  focuses  on  strengthening  the  government’s  internal  audit  capacity  to 
improve budget control, integrity, and public spending. The program initiates implementation of 
the approved internal audit strategic plan by drafting the workplan and conducting capacity 
development on risk analysis and performance based audits and tranche 1 policy conditions 
have been met.   
 
26.  Output 3: Improved public debt management. The JPAM is anchored on continuing 
macroeconomic  stability  and  fiscal  discipline  hence  supports  the  achievement  of  (i)  near-
attainment of the FY2013 aggregate fiscal targets adjusted for post-cyclone estimates; and (ii) 
the near-attainment of a trend of revenue performance in 3 consecutive fiscal years up to 30 
June 2012 of 22.5% of GDP in tax revenues and 3.7% of GDP in nontax revenues. 
 
27.  Given  the  deterioration  in  the  government’s  debt  situation,  it  was  agreed  with  the 
government that the program will focus on debt management and support. The tranche 1 
condition comprises the update of the medium-term debt strategy, this was approved by the 
cabinet in June 2013. The strategy reiterates the government’s commitment to targets relating 
to levels of concessionality of new debt taken. The strategy is published on MOF’s website, 
along with quarterly debt summary reports. As a second tranche condition, the program will help 
implement the medium-term debt management reform plan, which sets out how to (i) develop 
policies and processes for issuance of government guarantees and onlending; (ii) consider the 
best use of concessional budget support lending; and (iii) provide timely information to underpin 
decision making.  
 
28.  Output 4: Recovery and resilience to natural disasters. The program supports, as a 
tranche 1 condition, the government’s home-rebuilding scheme on condition that new homes 
will be built to climate-resilient standards. For tranche 2, the government shall approve the Apia 
Town Plan, which will incorporate guidelines to mitigate the risk of future natural disasters and 
their impact on the country’s fiscal situation. The town plan will have to ensure suitable zoning in 
floodplain areas and disaster risk reduction requirements for new urban construction. As a result 
of these measures, the infrastructure that is reconstructed after  cyclone Evan will be less 
susceptible to damage from future natural disasters, therefore reducing government’s fiscal risk. 
 
D.  Development Financing Needs 
 
29.  The government’s development financing needs for FY2014 and FY2015 are estimated 
at  $45  million,  to  be  funded  via  budget  support  from  ADB,  AusAID,  New  Zealand  Aid 
Programme, and the World Bank.  
 
30.  The  government  has  requested  a  grant  not  exceeding  $14  million  from  the  Asian 
Development Fund to help meet its development financing gap. The grant will be disbursed in 
two tranches—$10 million in FY2014 and $4 million in FY2015. The tranche disbursement is in 
line with the government’s request to frontload $10 million to meet a significantly higher deficit in 
FY2014 due to a much larger volume of reconstruction activities. 
 
31.  ADB is basing the size of its grant on the government’s reconstruction and recovery 
financing requirements, the fiscal impacts of implementing the JPAM, and the level of budget 
support to be provided by other development partners. Implementation of the MTFF will support 
post-cyclone reconstruction and growth in the near-to-medium term before fiscal consolidation 
brings debt down to sustainable levels. The total fiscal cost for recovery and reconstruction 
amounts to $166.90 million (or 24.5% of GDP) during FY2013–FY2015. Of this, 18.8% of GDP 
is accounted for through creation of fiscal space, i.e., expenditure reprioritization (equivalent to

8  
7.5% of GDP), donor project support (equivalent to 10.0% of GDP) and insurance payments 
(equivalent  to  1.3%  of  GDP).  Stronger  SOE  performance,  public  financial  management 
systems, debt management, and climate resilience combined with additional budget support 
grants could generate fiscal savings of about 5.0%–6.0% of GDP over the next 5 years, which 
would close the financing gap and help achieve fiscal consolidation. Budget support will come 
from ADB ($10.00 million in FY2014 and $4.00 million in FY2015), AusAID ($6.00 million and 
$3.82 million), New Zealand Aid Programme ($0.70 million and $0.80 million), and the World 
Bank ($15.00 million and $5.00 million).  
 
E.  Implementation Arrangements 
32.  Program management. MOF, as the executing agency, will oversee and coordinate the 
timely implementation of agreed policy, legal, and regulatory actions. It will also be responsible 
for achieving policy reforms and policy actions, for program administration, disbursements, 
maintenance of all program records, and for reporting to the development partners on program 
implementation progress and policy action achievements. The government, ADB, and other 
development partners will participate in the annual review of the PFMRP.  
 
33.  Implementation period and program review. The program is being implemented from 
31 March 2013 to 31 December 2015, consistent with the government’s MTFF. Policy and 
operational changes agreed with the government and set out in the policy matrix have been put 
in  place  from  31 March  2013  to  31 December  2014.  Reviews  will  be  conducted  through 
quarterly meetings between development partners and the government, and annually as part of 
the PFMRP review every November. Australia and New Zealand, as well as the EU, also 
conduct annual joint assessments of the JPAM prior to disbursements of their budget support. 
The assessments are shared with other development partners.  
 
34.  Procurement  and  disbursement.  The  proceeds  of  the  grant  will  be  disbursed  in 
accordance with ADB’s simplification of disbursement procedures and related requirements for 
policy-based grants.14 The proceeds will be used to finance the foreign exchange cost of items 
produced and procured in ADB member countries, excluding items included in a list of ineligible 
items  and  imports  financed  by  other  bilateral  and  multilateral  sources.15 Grant  proceeds 
disbursed against imports will require a certificate from the government stipulating that the value 
of the total imports of Samoa, minus its imports from nonmember countries, ineligible imports 
and imports financed under other official development assistance is greater than the amount of 
the grant expected to be disbursed during a particular year. ADB will have the right to audit the 
use of the grant proceeds, and to verify the accuracy of the government’s certification. 
 
35.  Tranches. The grant will be provided in two tranches and will become effective once 
ADB is satisfied that all conditions for the release of the first tranche, as specified in the policy 
matrix16 and set out in the grant agreement,17 have been complied with. The second tranche 
shall be disbursed once ADB is satisfied that all conditions for its release, as specified in the 
policy  matrix,  are  complied  with.  Second-tranche  conditions  should  be  completed  by 
31 December 2014.  
 
                                                
14 ADB. 1998. Simplification of Disbursement Procedures and Related Requirements for Program Loans. Manila. 
15 List of Ineligible Items (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2). 
16  The policy matrix is in Appendix 4. 
17  Grant agreement (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2).

9 
36.  Counterpart funds. Local currency generated from the grant will be directed to the 
government’s bank account with the Central Bank of Samoa to allow provision of supplementary 
financing for the FY2014 and FY2015 budgets. 
 
37.  Program performance monitoring and evaluation. MOF will establish a performance 
evaluation system for the program within 3 months from grant effectiveness and maintain this. 
Because the impact of the program will be felt beyond the period of its implementation, MOF will 
continue monitoring program performance until the end of 2015. The information will be included 
in the program completion report to be provided by the Government of Samoa.  
  
III.  DUE DILIGENCE 
38.  The program’s major benefit will be its contribution to the government’s goal of fiscal 
sustainability with stronger climate resilience. The program will support a continuation of the 
government’s  efforts  to  strengthen  its  public  financial  management  systems  through 
accelerating government reforms and contributing to more robust macroeconomic performance. 
The program will assist the government in maintaining fiscal stability through improvements to 
SOE performance, public financial management, and debt management, and through climate- 
proofing of infrastructure and homes. This will in turn raise the quality of public spending, 
alleviate the debt overhang, and strengthen Samoa’s resilience to natural disasters.  
 
A.  Economic and Financial 
39.  Once essential reconstruction requirements are met, budget restraint and strengthened 
fiscal  management  will  allow  the  government  to  lower  its  debt  burden  and  reduce  its 
vulnerability  to  fiscal  and  climatic  shocks.  Stronger  fiscal  management  will  also  help  the 
government  achieve  its  external  debt  target  of  50%  of  GDP  by  FY2020,  while  reducing 
vulnerability to climatic shocks. Implementation of SOE governance reforms will help improve 
their contribution to GDP as well as their financial performance, which will reduce the drain on 
the government’s budget (para. 15). 
 
B.  Governance 
40.  The  government’s  ability  to  mount  a  major  reconstruction  effort,  and  thereafter 
consolidate  public  spending,  is  integral  to  the  success  of  the  program.  The  emphasis  on 
improving public financial management in the JPAM process demonstrates the government’s 
strong commitment to managing public spending credibly and effectively, and to restoring fiscal 
sustainability in the medium term.  
 
41.  ADB’s  Anticorruption  Policy  (1998,  as  amended  to  date)  was  explained  to,  and 
discussed with, the government and MOF. Relevant provisions of ADB’s Anticorruption Policy 
are included in the grant agreement. 
 
C.  Poverty and Social 
42.  The program is categorized as a general intervention to support sustainable economic 
growth and is expected to contribute to poverty reduction indirectly.18 Stronger public financial 
management will contribute to macroeconomic stability, augment aggregate demand, enable 
effective delivery of essential services, and improve the business environment, all of which are 
                                                
18 Summary Poverty Reduction and Social Strategy (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2).

10  
necessary for inclusive growth and poverty reduction. Measures taken to strengthen climate 
resilience will improve the capacity of the poor to withstand environmental shocks.  
 
D.  Safeguards 
43.  In compliance with ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement (2009), the program is classified 
as category C for impacts on the environment, involuntary resettlement, and indigenous peoples.  
 
E.  Risks and Mitigating Measures 
44.  Major risks and mitigating measures are described in the risk assessment and risk 
management  plan.19 Major  risks  include  weak  institutional  and  human  capacity,  a  large 
reconstruction agenda, vulnerability to further climatic and economic shocks, and a changing 
political environment leading to limited commitment to reforms. The program is designed to 
mitigate these risks by supporting climate resilience measures and by harmonizing support from 
development partners in a focused agenda of jointly agreed reforms. To meet skills gaps, 
government staff resources will be supplemented with ongoing TA provided by ADB and other 
partners. Political consensus will be obtained and sustained through government ownership, 
and  leadership  of  the  JPAM  process  and  policy  dialogue  for  budget  support.  Quarterly 
monitoring of the fiscal situation will enable the government to make necessary adjustments to 
the budget should unanticipated shocks occur.  
 
IV.  ASSURANCES  
45.  The government has assured ADB that implementation of the program shall conform to 
all applicable ADB policies, including those concerning anticorruption measures, safeguards, 
gender, procurement, consulting services, and disbursement as described in detail in the grant 
agreement. 
 
46.  The government and the MOF have agreed with ADB on certain covenants for the 
program, which are set forth in the grant agreement. The grant will become effective after all 
conditions for the release of the first tranche, as specified in the policy matrix and set out in 
Attachment  2  to  Schedule  2  to  the  grant  agreement,  have  been  complied  with,  to  the 
satisfaction of ADB. 
 
V.  RECOMMENDATION 
47.  I am satisfied that the proposed policy-based grant would comply with the Articles of 
Agreement of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) and recommend that the Board approve the 
grant  of  $14,000,000  to  Independent  State  of  Samoa  for  the  Public  Sector  Financial 
Management  Program,  from  ADB’s  Special  Funds  resources;  and  such  other  terms  and 
conditions as are substantially in accordance with those set forth in the draft grant agreement 
presented to the Board. 
 
Takehiko Nakao
